name: Sermon on the Mount | Matthew 5-7
summary: The Sermon on the Mount (Matthew 5-7) is Jesus' first and longest discourse in Matthew's Gospel, delivered from a mountain in deliberate parallel to Moses receiving the Law on Mount Sinai. This 'Kingdom Constitution' establishes the ethical standards of God's kingdom through the Beatitudes, the 'You have heard... but I say' antitheses, teachings on prayer (including the Lord's Prayer), fasting, treasures, anxiety, judging, and the call to build one's life on Jesus' words. Matthew presents Jesus as the authoritative interpreter of Torah who reveals its heart-level intention.

keyPassages.title: The Beatitudes
keyPassages.text: Blessed are the poor in spirit, for theirs is the kingdom of heaven...
keyPassages.significance: Kingdom blessings declared - reversal of worldly values

keyPassages.title: Fulfillment of the Law
keyPassages.text: Do not think that I have come to abolish the Law or the Prophets; I have not come to abolish them but to fulfill them
keyPassages.significance: Jesus affirms Torah while claiming authority to give its definitive interpretation

keyPassages.title: The Six Antitheses
keyPassages.text: You have heard that it was said... But I say to you...
keyPassages.significance: Jesus interprets Torah at heart level, extending commands inward
keyPassages.corpusQuery: Matthew 5 you have heard but I say

keyPassages.title: The Lord's Prayer
keyPassages.text: Our Father in heaven, hallowed be your name...

keyPassages.title: Wise and Foolish Builders
keyPassages.text: Everyone who hears these words of mine and does them will be like a wise man who built his house on the rock
keyPassages.significance: Obedience to Jesus' teaching as foundation of life

keyPassages.title: Authority of Jesus
keyPassages.text: The crowds were astonished at his teaching, for he was teaching them as one who had authority, and not as their scribes
keyPassages.significance: Jesus' authority exceeds scribal tradition - like a new Moses

historicalContext: Delivered early in Jesus' Galilean ministry, the Sermon on the Mount establishes the ethical demands of the Kingdom. Matthew places it as the first of five major discourses, corresponding to the five books of Torah. The mountain setting evokes Sinai, where Moses received the Law.
structure: Three chapters organized thematically: 5:1-16 (Kingdom character), 5:17-48 (Torah interpretation), 6:1-18 (Private devotion), 6:19-34 (Trust in God), 7:1-27 (Wisdom for life)
influence: The most influential ethical teaching in human history, shaping Christian moral thought and inspiring countless movements for justice, peace, and personal holiness.

sinai_parallel.moses_on_sinai: Exodus 19-20: Moses ascends Sinai to receive the Law
sinai_parallel.jesus_on_mountain: Matthew 5:1: Jesus went up on the mountain and sat down (teaching position)
sinai_parallel.parallel_significance: Matthew presents Jesus as the new Moses giving authoritative Torah interpretation

not_abolish_but_fulfill.meaning: Jesus affirms Torah's validity while revealing its deeper intention
not_abolish_but_fulfill.jot_and_tittle: Not one jot or tittle will pass from the Law until all is accomplished (5:18)
not_abolish_but_fulfill.greater_righteousness: Unless your righteousness exceeds that of the scribes and Pharisees... (5:20)

antitheses_structure.pattern: 'You have heard that it was said (to those of old)... But I say to you'
antitheses_structure.authority: Jesus speaks with personal authority ('But I say') rather than citing rabbinic tradition

six_antitheses.jesus_interpretation: Everyone who is angry with his brother will be liable to judgment
six_antitheses.expansion: Murder extends to anger and contempt

six_antitheses.jesus_interpretation: Everyone who looks at a woman with lustful intent has already committed adultery in his heart
Everyone who divorces his wife, except on the ground of sexual immorality, makes her commit adultery
six_antitheses.expansion: Divorce restricted to protect marriage covenant

six_antitheses.torah_text: You shall not swear falsely (Leviticus 19:12, Numbers 30:2)
six_antitheses.jesus_interpretation: Do not take an oath at all... Let your 'yes' be 'yes' and your 'no' be 'no'

six_antitheses.torah_text: An eye for an eye and a tooth for a tooth (Exodus 21:24)
six_antitheses.jesus_interpretation: Do not resist the one who is evil. If anyone slaps you on the right cheek, turn to him the other also

six_antitheses.torah_text: Love your neighbor (Leviticus 19:18) and hate your enemy (not in Torah)
six_antitheses.jesus_interpretation: Love your enemies and pray for those who persecute you

heart_of_torah.description: Jesus reveals Torah's true intention: heart-level obedience, not merely external conformity
heart_of_torah.principle: Be perfect, as your heavenly Father is perfect (Matthew 5:48)
heart_of_torah.connection_to_shema: The Shema (Deuteronomy 6:4-5) calls for loving God with all heart - Jesus shows what this means

beatitudes.description: Eight (or nine) declarations of blessing that open the Sermon
beatitudes.structure: Each begins with 'Blessed are...' (Greek: makarioi) and describes kingdom character

beatitudes.text: Blessed are the poor in spirit, for theirs is the kingdom of heaven
beatitudes.meaning: Spiritual humility recognizing need for God

beatitudes.text: Blessed are those who mourn, for they shall be comforted
beatitudes.meaning: Grief over sin and brokenness met with divine comfort

beatitudes.text: Blessed are the meek, for they shall inherit the earth
beatitudes.meaning: Gentle strength that trusts God rather than self-assertion

beatitudes.text: Blessed are those who hunger and thirst for righteousness, for they shall be satisfied
beatitudes.meaning: Intense longing for justice and right relationship with God

beatitudes.text: Blessed are the merciful, for they shall receive mercy
beatitudes.meaning: Compassion extended to others brings divine mercy

beatitudes.text: Blessed are the pure in heart, for they shall see God
beatitudes.meaning: Inner purity leads to vision of God

beatitudes.text: Blessed are the peacemakers, for they shall be called sons of God
Blessed are those who are persecuted for righteousness' sake, for theirs is the kingdom of heaven
beatitudes.meaning: Suffering for Christ shares in prophetic heritage

structure.petition: Your will be done, on earth as it is in heaven
Give us this day our daily bread
Forgive us our debts, as we also have forgiven our debtors
Lead us not into temptation, but deliver us from evil
structure.significance: Protection from testing and the evil one

jewish_parallels.kaddish: Similarities to synagogue prayer - 'hallowed be your name'
jewish_parallels.significance: Jesus draws on Jewish prayer tradition while giving distinctive teaching

metadata.focus: Jesus as authoritative Torah interpreter, Sinai-Sermon parallel

description: The Sermon on the Mount (Matthew 5-7) is Jesus' first major discourse, delivered from a mountain in deliberate parallel to Moses receiving Torah on Sinai. Jesus presents the 'Kingdom Constitution' through the Beatitudes, the six 'You have heard... but I say' antitheses, the Lord's Prayer, and teachings on heart-level righteousness. Matthew presents Jesus as the new Moses who authoritatively interprets Torah, revealing its heart intention.
